facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 21 of 1962 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 21. of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated September 23, 1958 of Bombay High Court in I.T. Reference No. 87 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 23, 1958, of the Bombay High Court in I.T. Reference No. 87 of 1957.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by SHAH, J. on October 25, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. October 25. The judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.-

facts.text: Afco Private Ltd., a private limited company, earned total income of Rs. 49,843/- for year of account ending March 31, 1955, as computed by Income-tax Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: For the year of account ending March 31, 1955, Afco Private Ltd.-a private limited companypany-earned a total income which was finally companyputed in assessment proceedings by order of the Income-tax Tribunal, at Rs. 49,843/-.

facts.text: Afco Private Ltd. declared dividend of Rs. 11,712/- on July 13, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany declared a dividend of Rs. 11,7121- on July 13, 1955,

facts.text: Afco Private Ltd. declared additional dividend of Rs. 5,612/- before close of assessment year 1955-56.

anchor.surface_text: and before the close of the year of assessment 1955-56 declared an additional dividend of Rs.5,612/-,

facts.text: Total dividends distributed by Afco Private Ltd. were not less than 60% of total income reduced by income-tax and super-tax.

anchor.surface_text: thereby distributing in the aggregate dividend which was number less than 60 of the total income, reduced by the income-tax and super-tax payable by it.

facts.text: Afco Private Ltd. claimed rebate at one anna in the rupee under Finance Act 15 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany then claimed rebate at the rate of one anna in the rupee on the amount companyputed according to Schedule 1, Part 1, Item B read with s. 2 of the Finance Act 15 of 1955.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer rejected the rebate claim because provisions of s. 23A applicable to the company.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer and the Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected the claim because in their view the claimant was a companypany to which the provisions of s. 23A of the Income-tax Act companyld number be made applicable.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected the rebate claim.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer and the Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected the claim because in their view the claimant was a companypany to which the provisions of s. 23A of the Income-tax Act companyld number be made applicable.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Bombay reversed the order of Income-tax authorities.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Bombay , reversed the order of the Income-tax authorities.

facts.text: Tribunal held that rebate cannot be denied if conditions in s. 23A fulfilled.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal opined that the expression cannot be made applicable in Item B of Part 1 of Schedule 1 of Finance Act 15 of 1955 must be read in companyjunction with s. 23A of the Income-tax Act, and the benefit of rebate provided by the Finance Act, 1955, cannot be denied to a Private Company if the companyditions prescribed in s. 23A 1  are fulfilled.

facts.text: Question referred by Tribunal to Bombay High Court answered in affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: The following question referred by the Tribunal to the High Court of judicature at Bombay was answered in the affirmative - Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the assessee companypany having distributed dividends of over 60 of the companypanys total income less income-tax and super-tax payable thereon is entitled to the rebate of 1 anna per rupee on the undistributed balance of profits as provided in clause  1  of the proviso to item B of Part 1 of the 1st Schedule to the Finance Act of 1955 ?

facts.text: Supreme Court held assessee company entitled to rebate claimed.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the view that the High Court was right in holding that the companypany was entitled to the rebate claimed by it.
The companypany then claimed rebate at the rate of one anna in the rupee on the amount companyputed according to Schedule 1, Part 1, Item B read with s. 2 of the Finance Act 15 of 1955.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court applies interpretation of 'cannot be made applicable' to facts, agrees with High Court after analyzing text, procedure, and legislative history.

holdings.text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal and the High Court were right in holding that the expression 'cannot be made applicable' only refers to a state of affairs in which, having regard to the circumstances, an order under s. 23A of the Income-tax Act cannot be made.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal and the High Court held that the expression cannot be made applicable only refers to a state of affairs in which having regard to the circumstances an order under s. 23k of the Indian Income-tax Act cannot be made. In our judgment the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal and the High Court were right in so holding.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Endorses lower courts' view on phrase meaning situational justifiability of order, not class exclusion.

holdings.text: The Legislature has used the expression 'cannot be made applicable' which clearly means that the applicability of s. 23A depends upon an order to be made by the Income-tax Officer, and not upon any exclusion by the provisions of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal and the High Court were right in so holding. The Legislature has used the expression cannot be made applicable which clearly means that the applicability of s. 23A depends upon an order

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain textual interpretation ties applicability to ITO's discretionary order, rejecting automatic statutory bar for private companies.

holdings.text: The language used by the Legislature clearly indicates that it is only when an order under s. 23A will not, having regard to the circumstances, be justified that the right to obtain rebate under the Finance Act 15 of 1955 is claimable.
